comment.author: 8543109@N02
comment._content: Likely Charlotte Graveratte Kauffman Breitung, wife of Edward N. Breitung, who made his money in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan mines. The family seemed to have many scandals associated with them.

comment.author: 35075914@N06
comment._content: Thanks, logista, we'll add fuller name to record.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: NYT of February 7, 1915 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0E1EFE395B17738... reports that Edward N. Breitung had acquired the German steamship Dacia. This was an issue that led to congressional debates, with some arguing that such purchases would entangle the US in the war. Later in February 1915, the ship was captured by the French and was unable to immediately prove that she was a neutral ship. books.google.com/books?id=zlPjhO5WA5gC&pg=PA1016&... has more on the legal case that followed the capture. A picture of Mr. Breitung is at: www.pictorialgems.com/1915-Captain-Wood-Durward-Mr-Edward...

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Mrs. Breitung was an active philanthropist and member of New York society. See search.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/sse.dll?rank=1&gss=angs-d...
